newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan's Lee cast doubts on China succession.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan's Lee cast doubts on China succession.

text.p: Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui expressed doubts on Friday that Chinese President Jiang Zemin will succeed in replacing Deng Xiaoping as the mainland's top policy-maker and undisputed leader.
Deng, paramount leader and Long March veteran, died late on Wednesday aged 92. He had anointed Jiang, also Communist Party chief, as his heir.
It is widely believed the Party's key 15th Congress in October will provide a first major test for Jiang, 70, whose tenure as general secretary will be up for review.

"President Lee said he was not optimistic about Jiang Zemin's firm position for succession after Deng Xiaoping died," state-run television quoted Lee as telling a group of senior local newspaper executives.
Lee did not elaborate why he was not hopeful.
Lee, who offered in 1996 to make a peace journey to China and hold a meeting with Jiang, also slammed China's human rights record, saying China cannot compete with Taiwan on democracy.
"They (China) often talk about democracy, but their democracy is different. It is not democracy without human rights," Lee said on the television.
"Do they (China) dare to compete with us on democracy? I think they definitely dare not," Lee said.

Lee said on Friday that his government would continue to promote ties with China and predicted that long-suspended Taiwan-Beijing talks would resume next year if Jiang consolidated his power during the party congress in October.
The president said that, in the meantime, China's Communist leadership would be occupied by political transition and would not have time for negotiation with Taiwan.

China has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province since the Nationalists sought refuge there after losing the civil war on the mainland in 1949. Both governments say they want reunification but under very different terms.
Nineteen months ago, China clamped a freeze on what had been slowly warming unofficial ties with Taiwan after a controversial visit to the United States by Lee in June 1995.

Beijing, which interpreted Lee's private but high-profile trip as an attempt to promote independence for Nationalist-held Taiwan, later staged several missile tests near the island to warn the Taiwanese not to drop its commitment to reunification.
The war games hit the island's financial markets in early 1996 and triggered panic buying of U.S. dollars and gold.
Beijing refuses to drop its threat to use military force to retake the island should it declare independence.
Taiwan officials, including Lee, have urged people of the island not to overreact to Deng's death.
"We should not take this issue too seriously," Lee was quoted as telling a group of national assemblymen on Thursday.

"We have experienced the most dangerous missile crisis, so we should have confidence and not become unravelled," the Central Daily News newspaper, owned by the ruling Nationalist Party, quoted Lee as saying.
"It (Deng's death) happened and the stock market rose... We should set our heart at ease," Lee told the assemblymen.
The island's sensitive stock market has so far shrugged off political fears, rising 0.28 percent on Thursday and a further 1.47 percent on Friday.
"Nothing will be affected by them (China) and we have been prepared for a long time ago," the independent China Times newspaper quoted Lee as saying.
"Why should you worry if I am not worried?" Lee said.
